qas.question: Which ship was originally known as being the capital ship of the fleet?
When did aircraft carriers begin being know as the capital ship of the fleet?
What type of carrier is capable of displacing 75,000 tonnes or greater?
Which ships are used for carrying and landing Marines?
What do Amphibious assalut ships need a large contingent of for carrying Marines?
Which ship was never known as being the capital ship of the fleet?
When did aircraft carriers begin being know as the minor ship of the fleet?
What type of carrier is capable of displacing 57,000 tonnes or greater?
Which ships are used for carrying and landing Civilians?
What do Amphibious assault ships need a small contingent of for carrying Marines?

context: Modern navies that operate such aircraft carriers treat them as the capital ship of the fleet, a role previously held by <a0_0><b5_0>the battleship<b5_0/><a0_0/>. This change took place during <a1_0><b6_0>World War II<b6_0/><a1_0/> in response to air power becoming a significant factor in warfare, driven by the superior range, flexibility and effectiveness of carrier-launched aircraft. Following the war, carrier operations continued to increase in size and importance. <a2_0><b7_0>Supercarriers<b7_0/><a2_0/>, displacing 75,000 tonnes or greater, have become the pinnacle of carrier development. Some are powered by nuclear reactors and form the core of a fleet designed to operate far from home. <a3_0><b8_0>Amphibious assault ships<b8_0/><a3_0/>, such as USS Tarawa and HMS Ocean, serve the purpose of carrying and landing Marines, and operate a large contingent of <a4_0><b9_0>helicopters<b9_0/><a4_0/> for that purpose. Also known as "commando carriers" or "helicopter carriers", many have the capability to operate VSTOL aircraft.
